sec.title: Background
sec.p: Unorganized caregivers increasingly face significant challenges that impact their participation in the labor market, particularly in low- and middle-income countries. This paper explores the effects of both care intensity and the subjective caregiving burden on the labor force participation and work hours of these unorganized caregivers.

sec.title: Method
sec.p: We used data from a sample of 1,806 unorganized caregivers in Ghana who provide care to older adults aged 60 and above. High-intensive caregivers were classified as those providing at least 20 h of caregiving per week, while the caregiving burden was measured using the short version of the Zarit Burden Interview score. The results were based on the average marginal effect from a logistic regression model.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The results showed that both high-intensity and high-burden caregiving have notable effects on labor force participation and the work hours of unorganized caregivers. High-intensive caregivers were associated with an approximately 14% increase in the probability of reducing work hours. Also, high-burden caregivers were found to be associated with a 7% increase in the probability of being self-employed. The combined effect of high-intensity and high-burden caregiving was found to amplify the labor market challenges, particularly in reducing work hours and limiting the ability to maintain stable employment.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: These findings highlight the significant impact of unorganized caregiving on labor market outcomes, particularly for those providing intensive and high-burden care. Policymakers should consider these effects when designing support systems for caregivers to mitigate the negative impact on employment and income stability.​.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Caregiving for older adults is a crucial component of societal well-being, offering essential physical, emotional, and practical support to those who require assistance due to age, illness, or disability. While caregiving is widely recognized as a social responsibility that fosters communal ties and familial bonds, its structure and organization differ across various contexts. In many countries, particularly in Sub-Saharan Africa (SSA), caregiving for older adults is predominantly informal and unstructured, relying heavily on family members, friends, and neighbors without formal coordination or institutional support [1–3].

Research from SSA highlights the growing burden on caregivers as demographic shifts result in an increasing older population with complex care needs [4, 5]. However, the absence of strong social protection systems, limited access to formal long-term care services, and economic constraints mean that caregiving in the region remains largely unorganized. This lack of structure places significant strain on caregivers’ time, health, and financial stability, making it increasingly difficult for them to balance caregiving responsibilities with other aspects of their lives [6].

This paper adopts the World Health Organization’s definition of unorganized caregiving, which refers to care provided by family members or other unpaid caregivers without coordination beyond the household level [7]. These unorganized caregivers also provide support without institutional or formal assistance, which has significant implications for their labor market participation [8]. Existing research in various contexts consistently shows that caregiving responsibilities negatively affect caregivers’ employment status, work hours, and overall economic well-being [9, 10]. However, studies focusing on SSA remain scarce, and few of them have examined the intersection of caregiving intensity and labor market participation [11, 12].

Caregiving intensity, often measured by the number of hours devoted to caregiving, plays a crucial role in shaping labor market outcomes such as employment status and work hours. High-intensity caregivers who provide extensive hours of care each week are more likely to experience job instability, time poverty and workforce withdrawal. Studies in other contexts have found that intensive caregivers often reduce their working hours, take unpaid leave, or exit the labor market entirely [13].

Additionally, caregiving responsibilities in informal settings are often associated with increased physical and emotional stress, further undermining caregivers’ ability to engage in the labor market [14]. Specifically in Ghana, informal caregivers, particularly those caring for older adults, frequently report significant health-related quality-of-life challenges, including physical exhaustion, mental health strains, and financial burdens [15]. These challenges, in turn, limit their ability to maintain consistent and productive labor market participation.

Despite the essential role that unorganized caregivers play in supporting Ghana’s aging population, their labor market outcomes remain understudied. A key motivation for this study is the country’s rapidly aging demographic. As of 2021, individuals aged 60 years and above made up 6.5% of the population (1,991,736 older adults) [16]. This number is projected to rise to 2.8 million by 2030 and is estimated to reach 6.3 million by 2050 [17]. Research indicates that socio-demographic factors such as age are associated with increased disability among older adults in Ghana [18]. Consequently, the burden on unorganized caregivers, who are often invisible in national statistics, policy frameworks, and academic discourse, is expected to intensify as the population ages. At the same time, Ghana’s predominantly informal labor market heightens the relevance of this issue. With approximately 75% of the workforce employed informally, access to paid leave, job security, and social protection is limited [19]. This further compounds the burden on caregivers in the informal sector. These dynamics make Ghana a critical context for exploring the intersection of caregiving responsibilities and labor market outcomes.

Understanding the relationship between unorganized caregiving and labor market outcomes is essential for developing policies that support caregivers while ensuring economic productivity. The findings from this study are expected to inform social and labor policies that acknowledge and support the dual roles of unorganized caregivers in Ghana.

sec.title: Theoretical framework
sec.p: The theoretical framework for this study incorporates role strain, reciprocal family obligations, and resource availability in caregiving decisions [20]. The tenet of the framework combines role conflict theory and intergenerational exchange theory, providing a lens through which to examine how unorganized caregivers balance their dual roles as caregivers and labor force participants.

Role conflict theory suggests that individuals who occupy multiple roles, such as being both a caregiver and a wage earner, experience conflict due to the competing demands of each role. This theory postulates that the more intense or burdensome the caregiving role, the more severe the conflict, negatively impacting labor market outcomes such as employment status, wages, and job security. This conflict occurs when the time and energy devoted to caregiving responsibilities hinder effective participation in the labor market. Due to the limited formal caregiving institutions, unorganized caregivers in Ghana often manage unpaid caregiving duties with paid employment.

Since time is a limited resource, caregivers must make choices about how to allocate it effectively. Increased time spent on caregiving often comes at the expense of other activities such as employment, leisure, and sleep. Consequently, caregiving is expected to reduce labor market participation. However, a reduction in work hours also leads to lower income, prompting caregivers to weigh the financial trade-offs of cutting back on employment. Depending on the marginal cost of reducing work hours, caregivers may compensate for the time demands of caregiving by primarily sacrificing leisure and sleep rather than labor market activities. This raises important questions about the extent to which caregiving affects labor market participation.

Additionally, caregiving may introduce new financial burdens, such as medical expenses or transportation costs, which could further influence employment decisions. Under certain conditions, caregivers might maintain their work hours by sacrificing leisure and sleep, or they may even increase their labor market participation to offset caregiving-related financial pressures. The overall impact of caregiving on employment, therefore, depends on the complex interplay between time constraints, financial needs, and personal well-being.

The intergenerational exchange theory also explains caregiving as part of a reciprocal arrangement between generations within families. Adult children provide care for adult parents in exchange for their earlier support. In Ghana, strong family ties and cultural norms around filial responsibility often place the burden of caregiving on adult children, particularly women. The theory suggests that caregiving is not just a personal choice but is shaped by societal norms and familial obligations, which further compounds the economic challenges caregivers face.

sec.title: Design and participants
sec.p: The data for this study were collected from Greater Accra, Ashanti, and Northern regions of Ghana. These regions were purposively selected to reflect Ghana’s geographic and socioeconomic diversity. Greater Accra represents a highly urbanized setting with better access to formal services and infrastructure. Ashanti Region, a mix of urban and peri-urban areas, captures middle-income characteristics and dense population dynamics. The Northern Region reflects a predominantly rural context, marked by lower income levels and limited access to services. This regional spread allows the study of how caregiving intensity and burden affect labour market outcomes among unorganized caregivers across varied settings, thereby improving the generalizability and external validity of the findings.

The sampling frame included households from the 2021 Population and Housing Census (PHC) by the Ghana Statistical Service (GSS), specifically those with at least one older adult aged 60 or above who reported challenges in areas such as sight, hearing, mobility, cognitive function, self-care, or speech. GSS defines each Enumeration Area (EA) as an area averaging 750 households, with urban EAs generally larger than rural ones [21]. The sample was stratified into urban and rural groups within each region, forming six sampling strata. Sampling occurred in two stages, with proportional allocation applied to reflect the administrative hierarchy within each stratum. In the first stage, 200 EAs were selected (143 urban, 57 rural), serving as primary sampling units (PSUs). After conducting household listings in each EA, 10 households were randomly chosen per EA as secondary sampling units (SSUs), resulting in an initial total sample of 2,000 households. The 10 households were selected from each EA to achieve a balance between statistical representativeness and logistical feasibility.

With a response rate of 99.5%, the final sample included 1,990 households. These households comprised 1,990 older care recipients (60 years or older, with the capacity to respond) and their corresponding 1,990 caregivers, each 18 years or older. Considering the working age group in Ghana, caregivers above 64 years were dropped in this paper, leading to a total sample size of 1806 caregivers.

sec.title: Data collection
sec.p: The survey was conducted from July to August 2023 by 32 trained enumerators through a face-to-face interview using a validated questionnaire, which was programmed and uploaded onto Computer-Assisted Personal Interview (CAPI) software for data collection. The software helped pick the geographical coordinates of the household for revisiting, storing the data, and backing up the data in different storage systems. Before the interviews, enumerators made sure the selected household included a care receiver and respective caregivers, both of whom had to consent to partake in the survey before the interview could be conducted. Care receivers whose respective caregivers were unavailable were revisited until they were all available for the interview. Otherwise, they were excluded from the interview if at least one was unavailable. The absence of some caregivers resulted in a non-response rate of 0.05% (10 households) out of the total sample. The Ethical and Protocol Review Committee of the College of Health Sciences, University of Ghana, approved the survey protocol for this data collection.

sec.title: Dependent variables
sec.p: Labor Force Participation:

This measure captured the extensive margin of labor supply based on responses to three questions referring to the month preceding the study. Respondents were asked to answer ‘Yes’ or ‘No’ to the following: a) From the past one month, have you been unemployed? b) From the past month, have you been self-employed? c) From the past one month, have you been in paid employment? Those who answered ‘Yes’ to the unemployment question were subsequently asked whether they were actively seeking and available for work. Respondents who answered affirmatively were classified as unemployed; otherwise, they were considered outside the labor force. A ‘Yes’ response to any of the three labor force questions was coded as 1; otherwise, it was coded as 0.”

sec.title: Work hours
sec.p: This was derived from the question, “In the past one month have you had to do any of the following as a result of providing care for your care recipient? a) Work more hours at your job? b) Work fewer hours at your job? For each question, responses were “Yes” coded as 1 and “No” coded as 0 for any of the two questions. Those who responded “No” to all the two questions were classified as those who have maintained their working hours arriving at the third variable; c) Maintain work hours, coded as “1” for those who have maintained work hours and “0” if otherwise(increase or decrease work hours).

sec.title: Care intensity:
sec.p: This is derived from the number of hours of caregiving within a week. Caregivers who provided 20 h or more of caregiving per week were considered high-intensity caregivers. This benchmark is widely accepted and used in caregiving research. Many caregiving studies use 20 h per week because it has been found to have a significant effect on labor force participation [13, 14].

Caregiving burden: This was measured using the short version of the Zarit Burden Interview (ZBI) score [22]. The ZBI is the most used tool for assessing caregiver burden [23]. Its short version is also widely applied across diverse populations and cultural contexts due to its strong reliability and validity [24]. The ZBI score is based on 12 items in measuring the caregiving burden, which covers caregiving’s emotional, social, and physical dimensions. Each item is rated on a Likert scale from 0 (never) to 4 (nearly always), with higher scores indicating greater burden. The caregiving burden was classified into two: low-burden caregiving and high-burden caregiving. Scores within the fourth quartiles were considered high-burden caregivers, while those within the first to third quartiles were classified as low-burden caregivers [22].

sec.title: Age
sec.p: Age is an important determinant of both labor force participation and work hours. The relationship between age and labor force participation or work hours is influenced by factors such as life cycle, health status, skills, and institutional settings [25–27]. We expect labor force participation to decline as an individual grows, although some studies indicate the continuous engagement of the older population in subsistence or informal labor, especially in developing countries, due to the lack of comprehensive social security programs as well as financial insecurity and supplementing pension income [28]. We expect working hours to be influenced by age directly or through other related factors [29].

sec.title: Gender
sec.p: Gender plays a significant role in shaping both labor force participation and work hours. While gender gaps in labor force participation and work hours have been narrowing over time due to family-friendly policies, significant disparities remain due to factors such as caregiving responsibilities [30, 31].

sec.title: Educational level
sec.p: The level of education is considered by various studies as a key determinant of both labor force participation and work hours [32]. Higher education generally leads to higher participation rates and longer, more stable work hours, while lower education levels are associated with reduced participation and more variable or part-time work hours. The impact of education is profound, as it influences access to opportunities, job stability, and overall career trajectories.

sec.title: Marital status
sec.p: Marital status significantly influences labor force participation and work hours. For instance, during periods of declining fertility, married women tend to participate in the labor force at higher rates [33]. Additionally, research indicates that divorced or separated women generally work more than their male counterparts [34].

sec.title: Personal monthly income
sec.p: The relationship between personal income, labor force participation, and work hours is shaped by economic incentives, job characteristics, and lifestyle choices. Low-income earners also tend to increase their working hours to manage financial uncertainty [35]. Also, it has been found that higher-income earners tend to have a greater balance between work and leisure, although some studies have found that high monthly income comes at the expense of leisure [36].

Household Size Household size has been shown to significantly impact labor force participation and work hours. The number of dependents or household members often influences economic pressures and time allocation. The larger the household, the more likely members are to adjust their participation in the labor force and their work hours to meet the household’s economic needs, caregiving responsibilities, and division of labor [37].

sec.title: Years of caregiving
sec.p: The relationship between years of caregiving and labor force participation or work hours is characterized by a cumulative reduction in workforce engagement as caregiving responsibilities extend over time. It has been found that long-term caregivers providing high-intensive care are more likely to be completely retired or not participate in the labor force [38].

sec.title: Living arrangement with care receiver
sec.p: Living in the same household with a care receiver is expected to affect labor force participation and work hours for caregivers. Caregivers who reside with the care recipient face more immediate and continuous caregiving demands and limited flexibility, which often results in reduced labor force participation, reduction in work hours and entirely leaving the labor market [39]. The impact varies depending on various factors as it has been found that residing with older adults requiring assistance reduces working hours and the likelihood of full-time employment among younger women while increasing working hours and the probability of full-time employment among younger men [40].

sec.title: ADL limitations of care receiver
sec.p: Providing care for individuals with Activities of Daily Living (ADL) limitations has a profound effect on caregivers’ ability to participate in the labor force and manage their work schedules. ADL limitations, such as difficulties with bathing, dressing, eating, or mobility, demand significant time, attention, and physical effort from caregivers, increasing their overall burden. As a result, many caregivers are compelled to adjust their employment status by reducing work hours shifting to part-time work, or, in some cases, leaving the labor market entirely [14].

sec.title: Locality
sec.p: Locality influences employment opportunities, the nature of jobs, the structure of the labor market, and caregiving responsibilities. Rural workers are more likely to engage in self-employment with longer and more unregulated hours than urban workers [41, 42].

sec.title: Model specification
Descriptive statistics
sec.p: Table 1 shows caregivers’ demographic, socioeconomic, health, and caregiving-related characteristics stratified by care intensity (low vs. high) and caregiving burden (low vs. high). The average age of caregivers was 41 years, but the average age of those providing high-intensity care was slightly higher than those providing low-intensity care. Similarly, the average age of caregivers with a high burden was higher than those experiencing a low burden. 88% (88%) of the caregivers were females. Gender differences were significant for both caregiving intensity and burden, with a larger percentage of females providing high-intensive care and higher burden. The highest level of education for most of the caregivers, representing 53.6%, was Primary and Junior High School (JHS). While 53.4% are married, these married caregivers dominated the proportion of the marital status category who provide high-intensive care and high burden.

sec.p: The average personal monthly income of caregivers was GHS 711, while caregivers providing high-intensive care have a higher average personal monthly income than those in low-intensive care. Also, caregivers with high burdens report lower average income than those with low burdens. While 79.4% of caregivers have provided care for more than three years, 83% of caregivers live with their respective care receivers with an average household size of 5. The presence of ADL limitations in care receivers is more common within the categories of caregivers providing high-intensity and high-burden compared to their respective counterparts. Many of the respondents, representing 72%, lived in urban areas. Except for marital status, household size and locality, the chi-square and t-test conducted indicated a statistically significant association between all the independent variables and care intensity, while household size was the only variable that did not indicate a significant association with caregiving burden.

sec.title: Main results
sec.p: Table 2 presents the main results of the effects of care intensity and the subjective caregiving burden on the labor force participation and work hours of unorganized caregivers discussed under the subsections below.

sec.title: Labor force participation and caregiving
sec.p: Focusing on the relationship between caregiving and labor force participation, the results show that a caregiver who experiences a high caregiving burden was associated with an approximately 8% decrease in the probability of being unemployed. Rather, a high caregiving burden was associated with a 7% increase in the probability of being self-employed. Similarly, the interaction effect between high-intensity and high-burden caregiving showed a 7.5% reduction in the probability of being unemployed and a 6.8% increase in the probability of being self-employed. Regarding paid employment, results across all caregiving categories were not statistically significant.

sec.title: Maintaining work hours
sec.p: High-intensive caregivers were associated with an approximate 20% reduction in the probability of maintaining work hours compared to low-intensive caregivers. Similarly, high-burden caregivers were associated with an approximately 8% reduction in the probability of maintaining work hours. Those facing both high-intensive and high-burden caregiving were also associated with an approximately 9% increase in the probability of not maintaining consistent working hours.

sec.title: Reduced work hours
sec.p: High-intensive caregivers were associated with an approximately 14% increase in the probability of reducing work hours. Also, high-burden caregivers were associated with an approximately 8% increase in the probability of reducing work hours. Similarly, caregivers facing both high-intensive and high burdens were also associated with an approximately 10% increase in the probability of reducing work hours.

sec.title: Increase work hours
sec.p: High-intensive caregivers were associated with approximately 7% increase in the probability of increasing work hours.

sec.title: Labor force participation and caregiving
sec.p: Table A1 in the appendix shows the full results, providing additional insights into how various socio-economic factors influence labor force participation. The results show that older caregivers were more likely to be self-employed but less likely to be in paid employment. Caregivers having a primary or JHS education as their highest level of education were more likely to be unemployed and less likely to be self-employed. Caregivers with secondary or tertiary education were more likely to be unemployed although they are more associated with paid employment in the labor market and less likely to be self-employed workers.

Married or partnered caregivers were less likely to be unemployed and more likely to be self-employed similar to those divorced or separated. A high personal monthly income decreases the likelihood of unemployment while increasing the chances of self-employment and paid employment. Caregivers in larger households were less likely to be unemployed and associated with self-employment. Caregivers who have been providing care for more than three years were less likely to be unemployed and more associated with self-employment. Caregivers living in the same household as the care recipient were more likely to be unemployed. When the care recipient has limitations in Activities of Daily Living (ADLs), caregivers were less likely to be self-employed but more likely to be in paid employment. Urban caregivers were less likely to be self-employed and more likely to be paid-employed compared to caregivers in rural areas.

sec.title: Work hours and caregiving
sec.p: Table A2 in the appendix shows the full results of how caregiving characteristics and socio-economic factors influence the probability of caregivers maintaining, reducing, or increasing their working hours for those who are employed. The results showed that a higher personal monthly income reduces the probability of maintaining work hours but increases the probability of reducing or increasing work hours. An increase in household size was associated with a decrease in the likelihood of maintaining work hours as it is associated with a decrease in work hours. Caregivers who have been providing care for over 3 years were less likely to maintain their work hours as they are associated with reducing work hours.

sec.title: Sub-sample analysis of work hours by employment status
sec.p: The work hour model was re-estimated to know the effects of care intensity and caregiving burden on work hours segregated by employment status. Table 3 presents the main results of the estimation. The results showed that changes in work hours as a result of caregiving were significantly associated with self-employed caregivers. Caregivers who were self-employed and providing high intensive care were less likely to maintain regular working hours.

Self-employed who are providing high intensive care were associated with approximately 14% reduction in work hours although the results show the likelihood of some intensive caregivers increasing work hours by approximately 6%. Self-employed who are experiencing a high caregiving burden were associated with approximately 10% reduction in work hours while those involved in high intensive and experiencing a high burden were associated with approximately 12% reduction in work hours.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The results have indicated that a higher caregiving burden is linked to a decrease in the probability of unemployment and an increased probability of self-employment. The discussion highlights that caregivers in Ghana often move into self-employment due to the lack of flexibility in formal employment. This aligns with the role conflict theory, which suggests that when work and caregiving responsibilities clash, individuals seek alternative work arrangements, such as self-employment, to balance both roles. This is contrary to some studies where the caregiving burden significantly reduces the likelihood of being employed or reducing work hours [43, 44].

High-intensive and high-burden caregivers showed a significant reduction in maintaining regular working hours. The consequences of this have been found to cause a reduction in work hours [45]. These patterns suggest that caregivers may scale back their work involvement to accommodate the demands of caregiving. As many caregivers feel obligated to continue providing care regardless of reducing work hours, it mirrors the intergenerational exchange theory’s premise that caregiving is driven by social norms rather than purely economic considerations.

Interestingly, despite the challenges posed by caregiving, some caregivers, particularly those in high-intensive situations, exhibited an increase in the probability of increasing work hours. This reflects the time-allocation dilemma described in the theoretical framework, where caregivers must decide whether to reduce work hours, sacrifice leisure/sleep, or increase work hours to meet financial needs. This phenomenon has been noted in studies where some caregivers, especially those in lower-income brackets, may be forced to work longer hours despite the physical and emotional toll of caregiving [46]. The findings reinforce the idea that caregivers are not just making rational labor market choices but are influenced by deeply ingrained societal expectations, making policy interventions crucial.

It was also found that self-employed caregivers experience the most significant changes in work hours due to caregiving responsibilities​. While self-employment offers greater flexibility, it also comes with less formal support, such as paid leave or employer-sponsored caregiving benefits, which may explain why self-employed caregivers are more likely to adjust their work hours. The trade-off between flexibility and the demand for caregiving is well-established in literature. For example, it has been found that hired care workers because of increasing workloads, health risks, poverty and discrimination force them to choose self-employment [47]. Moreover, the findings highlighted that although some self-employed caregivers may increase their work hours to compensate for caregiving costs, they are still more likely to reduce work hours, reflecting the ongoing struggle to balance these competing demands.

The results provided additional insight into how various socio-economic factors in the estimation influence labor force participation and work hours. The less likelihood of a decrease in paid employment as age increases is an indication of the decrease in formal employment as an individual approaches retirement age [25]. Caregivers having a primary or JHS education as their highest level of education were associated with unemployment indicating the association of lower levels of education with higher unemployment and less entrepreneurial activity [32]. Married caregivers were less likely to be unemployed, often transitioning to self-employment to achieve financial stability while providing care. Similarly, divorced individuals also showed a higher likelihood of self-employment, reflecting the financial pressures and need for flexibility commonly experienced by this group.

Personal monthly income was found to be positively associated with self-employment and paid employment but can either influence an increase or decrease in work hours. This is in support of research that indicates a positive association between income levels and work hours. However, this relationship diminishes beyond a certain income threshold, suggesting that higher-income individuals may choose to work fewer hours to achieve a better work-life balance [48]. Higher-income earners often have the financial means to outsource caregiving responsibilities, enabling them to maintain or increase their labor market participation. For instance, it has been found that caregivers in Ghana spent an average of 219.5 h per month providing care [49]. This could limit their employment opportunities, hence, outsourcing such care can alleviate this burden, allowing for greater flexibility in work hours.

An increase in household size was more strongly associated with self-employment and less with paid employment. However, this positive relationship contrasts with previous findings, which identified factors such as age, education, prior work experience, and household headship as key determinants of self-employment in Ghana [50, 51]. This emerging trend may be driven by unorganized caregivers who turn to self-employment as a flexible work arrangement, allowing them to manage caregiving responsibilities while securing sufficient resources for their household needs. The likelihood of self-employed caregivers reducing their normal working hours as household size increases may be attributed to the freedom and flexibility that self-employment offers. This flexibility helps them manage work-family imbalances, a common challenge in entrepreneurial activities. Similar trends have been observed in countries like Nigeria [52]. Additionally, this flexibility in self-employment may explain why caregivers who have provided care for over three years are also more likely to engage in self-employment.

This study’s strengths include a robust and representative data collection methodology that ensures comprehensive coverage of Ghana’s diverse demographic and geographic landscape, enhancing the generalizability of findings. By targeting households with older adults (aged 60+) experiencing challenges in areas like mobility or self-care, the sample accurately reflects the population of interest. An exceptional response rate of 99.5% further underscores the reliability and comprehensiveness of the data, providing a solid foundation for meaningful analysis and inference.

Aside from the strength of the study, a notable limitation of this study arises from the potential endogeneity of care intensity and caregiving burden. The relationship between informal caregiving and labor force participation or work hours remains complex and bidirectional, making it difficult to establish clear causal links. On one hand, caregiving responsibilities may limit an individual’s ability to participate in the labor force or reduce their working hours. On the other hand, individuals with fewer labor market opportunities, such as lower wages or limited job prospects, may be more inclined to take on informal caregiving roles. This dual dynamic creates a feedback loop, complicating efforts to disentangle causality.

Also, in many cases, decisions about labor force participation, work hours, and caregiving are not made independently but are instead jointly determined within families. Thus, families often allocate caregiving responsibilities and labor force involvement based on overall needs and available resources, further entangling these variables. This simultaneity introduces endogeneity into the analysis, as caregiving and labor force behaviors influence each other.

Previous literature reflects this ambiguity. Some studies found care intensity as endogenous when estimating caregiving’s effects on labor force participation while others found otherwise [53, 54]. These mixed findings highlight the complexity of the issue and underscore the challenges of accurately modelling the relationship between caregiving and labor force dynamics.

A major challenge in addressing endogeneity in this context is the lack of strong and valid instrumental variables (IVs). Good instruments are crucial for isolating the causal impact of caregiving on labor outcomes. However, our data do not include such instruments, which constrained our ability to apply IV regression techniques. Employing weak instruments could result in biased and unreliable IV regression estimates [55]. Consequently, we chose to refrain from using IV regression, acknowledging the potential limitations this decision imposes on causal inference.

It is important to recognize that this limitation does not invalidate the observed associations between caregiving and labor force participation or work hours. While the absence of strong instruments limits our ability to fully address endogeneity, the findings presented in this study remain, to some extent, valid and reliable. Nonetheless, future research should strive to identify robust instruments or alternative methodological approaches to better address endogeneity in this context. This would provide a clearer understanding of the causal relationship between caregiving responsibilities and labor force outcomes, ultimately enriching the evidence base and informing policy decisions more effectively.

Another limitation of this study is that, while it provides valuable insights into the relationship between caregiving burden and employment outcomes, the generalizability of the findings may be constrained by the specific characteristics of the sample. Most participants were high-intensive caregivers, which may not fully represent the experiences of occasional or low-burden caregivers. Also, the study was conducted in Ghana, where specific cultural and policy factors, such as access to flexible work arrangements, may differ from other settings. Future research should examine whether these findings hold in diverse geographic, cultural, and policy contexts to enhance the external validity of the results.

sec.title: Policy and practical recommendations
sec.p: The findings of this study have important policy and practical implications, particularly in addressing the challenges faced by unorganized caregivers of older adults in Ghana. The study highlights the negative impact of unorganized caregiving on labor market participation, emphasizing the need for targeted interventions to support caregivers while ensuring economic productivity. To mitigate the financial burden of unorganized caregiving, policymakers should consider introducing caregiver support policies such as financial assistance, tax incentives, or social security benefits. Additionally, flexible work arrangements, including remote work options and paid caregiving leave, could help unorganized caregivers balance their work and caregiving responsibilities, reducing the risk of job loss or income instability.

The absence of formal caregiving support further increases the burden on unorganized caregivers. Investing in community-based long-term care services, such as subsidized home care programs and adult day-care centers, would provide crucial relief while enhancing the well-being of older adults. Strengthening these support systems would allow caregivers to participate more actively in the labor market without compromising the quality of care provided.

Beyond policy interventions, practical measures are also necessary. Organizations and community groups should implement caregiver training programs to enhance skills in the care of older adults, stress management, and time management. Establishing caregiver support groups can offer emotional and social support, reducing burnout. Additionally, public awareness campaigns and advocacy efforts can elevate the societal recognition of unorganized caregiving as essential work, encouraging stronger institutional support and funding. A coordinated approach involving healthcare providers, social workers, and policymakers would also ensure that caregivers receive the necessary guidance, resources, and referrals to available support systems, ultimately benefiting both caregivers and care receivers.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The findings underscore a strong relationship between caregiving responsibilities and labor market outcomes, particularly labor force participation and work hours. The caregiving burden significantly influenced labor market choices, often steering caregivers toward self-employment. High-intensity caregivers were less likely to sustain regular work hours and more inclined to reduce their working hours. This represents a loss to the caregiver and a loss to society. The results underscore the labor market consequences for unorganized caregivers, particularly those in high high-intensive or subjective high-burden caregiving roles and particularly in society settings that lack comprehensive labor policies. Addressing the policy and practical implications, Ghana can create a more supportive environment for caregivers, ensuring both economic productivity and improved well-being for caregivers and older adults alike.
